go.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
go.translation[0].definitions[0].example: There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.
Have you ever been to (=have you ever travelled to) Japan?
I have been to (=have travelled to) Germany several times.
We’re going to Canada in the summer.
She went over and put her arm around him.
I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.
I’ll just go up  (=go upstairs) and ask him what he wants.
go.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: to move or travel in a particular way or for a particular distance
go.translation[0].definitions[1].example: It took us over an hour to go ten miles.
The car was going much too fast.
We went a different way from usual that day.
It’ll be quicker to go by train.
go.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: to move to a particular place in order to do something
go.translation[0].definitions[2].example: I went and spoke to the manager.
go.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: to be at a concert, party, meeting etc
go.translation[0].definitions[3].example: Are you going to Manuela’s party?
I first went to a rock concert when I was 15.
go.translation[0].definitions[4].definit: to regularly attend school, a church etc
go.translation[0].definitions[4].example: He doesn’t go to the synagogue these days.
go.translation[0].definitions[5].example: What time does the last train go?
It’s late! I must get going.
go.translation[0].definitions[6].definit: to leave the place where you are, in order to do something
go.translation[0].definitions[6].example: I need to go shopping this afternoon.
My parents are going on a cruise.
go.translation[0].definitions[7].definit: to change in some way, especially by becoming worse than before
go.translation[0].definitions[7].example: The company went bankrupt last year.
Her hair is starting to go grey.
He went crazy and tried to kill her.
The crowd was going wild with excitement.
go.translation[0].definitions[7].note_bo: Go is used as a linking verb in this meaning It links the subject of the sentence with an adjective
I felt my face go red
go.translation[0].definitions[8].definit: to happen or develop in a particular way
go.translation[0].definitions[8].example: How did your French test go?
I feel very encouraged by the way things are going.
Many industries have been forced to cut jobs and it looks like the electronics industry is going the same way.
Everything’s going fine at the moment.
go.translation[0].definitions[9].definit: to reach as far as a particular place or to lead to a particular place
go.translation[0].definitions[9].example: The road goes through the middle of the forest.
The belt won’t go around my waist.
go.translation[0].definitions[10].type: intransitive always + adverb/preposition, not in progressive
go.translation[0].definitions[10].defini: if something goes somewhere, that is its usual position
go.translation[0].definitions[10].exampl: The book goes on the top shelf.
go.translation[0].definitions[11].defini: to be the right size, shape, or amount for a particular space
go.translation[0].definitions[11].exampl: I don’t think all that will go in the suitcase.
go.translation[0].definitions[12].defini: to be sent or passed on
go.translation[0].definitions[12].exampl: The email went to everyone in the company.
That letter should go by special delivery.
Complaints must go through the proper channels.
go.translation[0].definitions[13].defini: to be in a particular state or condition, especially a bad one
go.translation[0].definitions[13].exampl: Many families are forced to go hungry.
go.translation[0].definitions[14].exampl: The preparations have been completed and we’re ready to go.
Generally the action doesn’t get going (=start) until after midnight.
I’m going to get going on (=start doing) the decorating next week.
go.translation[0].definitions[15].defini: if a clock, watch, or machine goes, it moves and works as it should do
go.translation[0].definitions[15].exampl: I couldn’t get the pump going (=make it work).
go.translation[0].definitions[16].defini: used when you are telling someone about what movement someone or something made
go.translation[0].definitions[16].exampl: She went like this with her hand.
go.translation[0].definitions[17].exampl: I asked her what she meant and she just went, ‘Don’t ask!’
go.translation[0].definitions[19].defini: used to talk about what something such as a story or song consists of
go.translation[0].definitions[19].exampl: We need to ‘spread a little happiness’, as the song goes.
The story goes that my grandfather saved his captain’s life in battle.
go.translation[0].definitions[19].note_b: In this meaning, go is not used in the progressive You say
I don’t know how the song goes
I don’t know how the song is going
go.translation[0].definitions[20].defini: to make a noise as a warning or signal
go.translation[0].definitions[20].exampl: A bell goes to mark the end of each class.
go.translation[0].definitions[21].defini: to no longer exist or no longer be in the same place
go.translation[0].definitions[21].exampl: The door was open and all his things had gone.
go.translation[0].definitions[22].defini: if one of your senses such as sight, hearing etc is going, it is getting worse
go.translation[0].definitions[22].exampl: Dad’s eyesight is starting to go.
I’d forgotten that. My mind must be going.
go.translation[0].definitions[23].defini: if what someone says goes, that person is in authority and what they say should be obeyed
go.translation[0].definitions[23].exampl: Phil’s in charge, and what he says goes.
go.translation[0].definitions[24].defini: to become weak, damaged etc, or stop working properly
go.translation[0].definitions[24].exampl: The bulb’s gone in the bathroom.
My jeans are starting to go at the knee.
go.translation[0].definitions[25].defini: to die – use this when you want to avoid saying the word ‘die’
go.translation[0].definitions[25].exampl: Now that his wife’s gone, he’s all on his own.
When I go, I’d like to have my ashes scattered at sea.
go.translation[0].definitions[26].exampl: I don’t know where all my money goes!
Half her salary goes on the rent.
go.translation[0].definitions[27].exampl: He bought me some CDs which were going cheap (=were being sold at a low price).
A house like this would go for £250,000.
The jewels will go to the highest bidder.
go.translation[0].definitions[28].defini: to offer a particular amount of money for something
go.translation[0].definitions[28].exampl: I’ll give you $500 for it but I can’t go any higher than that.
I think we could probably go to £15,000.
go.translation[0].definitions[29].defini: used to say how quickly or slowly time passes
go.translation[0].definitions[29].exampl: The day seemed to go so slowly.
go.translation[0].definitions[30].defini: if colours, tastes, styles etc go, they look, taste etc good together
go.translation[0].definitions[30].exampl: I don’t think pink and yellow really go.
Do you think this shirt will go with the skirt I bought?
Pork and apple go especially well together.
go.translation[0].definitions[31].defini: to leave your job, especially because you are forced to
go.translation[0].definitions[31].exampl: He was becoming an embarrassment to the government and had to go.
If Jill goes, who will take her place?
go.translation[0].definitions[32].defini: if something goes, someone gets rid of it
go.translation[0].definitions[32].exampl: The policies will have to go if the party is to win the next election.
A hundred jobs are expected to go following the merger.
go.translation[0].definitions[33].defini: to make waste come out of your body
go.translation[1].definitions[0].example: ‘I can’t open this drawer.’ ‘Here, let me have a go.’
On the tour, everyone can have a go at making a pot.
I’d thought about it for some time and decided to give it a go (=try to do something).
I had a good go (=tried hard) at cleaning the silver.
I’m not sure it will work but it’s worth a go.
Ruby blew out all her candles at one go.
go.translation[1].definitions[1].definit: someone’s turn in a game or someone’s turn to use something
go.translation[1].definitions[1].example: Can I have a go on your guitar?
go.translation[1].definitions[2].definit: energy and a desire to do things
go.translation[1].definitions[2].example: There’s plenty of go in him yet.
go.translation[2].definitions[0].definit: to be sold for a particular amount or to a particular person
go.translation[2].definitions[0].example: He believes GM shares will fetch $45 by the year-end, while Ford will go for 40.
Government spending in the area doubled, but most of it went to the oil industry.
go.translation[2].definitions[1].definit: to do something on your own, for example to start a new business
go.translation[2].definitions[1].example: Unless an entrepreneur wants to go it alone and has the necessary money and talents, he or she may have to take on a partner.
go.translation[2].definitions[2].definit: used before an adjective or adjectival phrase to mean that something has happened or been done in a particular way. For example, if someone goes BANKRUPT,  they become bankrupt; if a company goes GLOBAL, it starts doing business all over the world
